<P STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT:13.0PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:2PT;BORDER-BOTTOM:1PX SOLID #000000;WIDTH:16%">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:8PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="3%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	&nbsp;(1)
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	Primarily includes government agency pass-through securities guaranteed by a government agency or government sponsored enterprise, among other types of RMBS.
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:8PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="3%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	&nbsp;(2)
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	Includes $903.8&nbsp;million and $946.7&nbsp;million of collateralized loan obligations as of December&nbsp;31, 2016 and 2015, respectively.
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:8PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="3%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	&nbsp;(3)
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	Includes partnership and
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	non-marketable
</FONT>
	equity investments accounted for on an AFS basis, and excludes investments accounted for using the equity method.
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:5%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	In 2016, there were transfers of $20.2&nbsp;million of securities out of Level&nbsp;3 that were principally due to an increase in observable
	inputs related to the valuation of such assets and, specifically, an increase in broker quotes. Of the $20.2&nbsp;million of transfers, $8.6&nbsp;million related to U.S. corporate bonds, $5.8&nbsp;million related to CMBS and $5.8&nbsp;million
	related to several other types of securities.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:5%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	In 2016, there were transfers of $10.6&nbsp;million of securities into Level&nbsp;3 that
	were principally due to a decrease in observable inputs related to the valuation of such assets and, specifically, a decrease in broker quotes. Of the $10.6&nbsp;million of transfers, $7.3&nbsp;million related to U.S. corporate bonds,
	$1.9&nbsp;million related to foreign corporate bonds and $1.4&nbsp;million related to common stock. There were no other material transfers between Levels 1, 2 or 3 in 2016.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:5%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	In 2015, there were transfers of $22.9&nbsp;million of securities out of Level&nbsp;3 that were principally due to an increase in observable
	inputs related to the valuation of such assets. Of the $22.9&nbsp;million of transfers, $15.9&nbsp;million related to U.S. corporate bonds, $5.5&nbsp;million related to foreign corporate bonds and $1.5&nbsp;million related to other invested assets.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:5%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	In 2015, there were transfers of $19.9&nbsp;million of securities into Level&nbsp;3 that were principally due to a decrease in observable
	inputs related to the valuation of such assets. Of the $19.9&nbsp;million of transfers, $14.2&nbsp;million related to U.S. corporate bonds, $5.0&nbsp;million related to other invested assets and $0.7&nbsp;million related to foreign corporate bonds.
	There were no other transfers between Levels 1, 2 or 3 in 2015.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	138
</P>

<TD VALIGN="TOP">

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:5%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<I>
	(b) Contractual Maturity
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:5%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The amortized cost or cost and the estimated fair value of debt securities by contractual maturity as of December&nbsp;31, 2016 are shown
	below. Expected maturities will differ from contractual maturities because borrowers may have the right to call or prepay obligations with or without call or prepayment penalties.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:5%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	As of December&nbsp;31, 2016,
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	non-income
</FONT>
	producing invested assets were insignificant.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:5%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<I>
	(d) Realized Gains and Losses
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:5%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The proceeds from sales of AFS securities were $7.0&nbsp;billion, $9.6&nbsp;billion and $6.6&nbsp;billion in 2016, 2015 and 2014, respectively.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:5%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Realized capital gains and losses in 2016 primarily reflect sales of equity and debt securities. Realized capital gains and losses for
	2015 and 2014 generally reflect sales of equity securities. In addition, Alleghany Capital recognized a $98.8&nbsp;million capital loss due to an impairment charge from a write-down of certain SORC assets in 2016 and a gain of $13.2&nbsp;million on
	April&nbsp;15, 2016 in connection with its acquisition of an additional 50&nbsp;percent equity ownership in Jazwares, when its
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	pre-existing
</FONT>
	30&nbsp;percent equity ownership was remeasured at estimated fair
	value (the &#147;Jazwares Remeasurement Gain&#148;).
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:5%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The SORC assets that were written-down relate specifically to SORC&#146;s acquisition
	of a certain legacy oil field for the sole purpose of applying enhanced oil recovery techniques. After completing construction of its underground facility in 2014, SORC commenced its drilling program in 2015. The drilling program, however, was
	delayed by third-party equipment problems that have since been corrected as well as a longer than expected
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	trial-and-error
</FONT>
</FONT>
	process determining the optimum well
	completion technique for
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	141
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage114"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D308070D10K_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	the reservoir, and efforts to address a lack of vertical permeability in the reservoir formation. SORC engaged a third-party petroleum engineering firm to provide an assessment of its
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	oil-recovery
</FONT>
	prospects and based on this assessment and other factors including oil prices, SORC wrote-down its legacy oil field assets to estimated fair value as of December&nbsp;31, 2016.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:5%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Realized capital gains from equity securities in 2015 include the sales of certain equity securities resulting from a partial restructuring of
	the equity portfolio, the sales of certain equity securities which had their cost basis reduced in earlier periods for the recognition of OTTI losses, and a $25.8&nbsp;million capital loss due to an impairment charge related to a
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	write-off
</FONT>
	of Alleghany&#146;s investment in ORX. Net realized capital gains in 2014 include a realized capital gain of $34.0&nbsp;million from the sales of long-dated U.S. Treasury Strip debt securities in April
	2014, some additional realized capital gains taken on debt securities and a $9.4&nbsp;million realized capital loss on the early redemption of $300&nbsp;million par value of TransRe&#146;s 5.75% senior notes due on December&nbsp;14, 2015 (the
	&#147;2015 Senior Notes&#148;). See Note 8(b) for additional information on the early redemption of the 2015 Senior Notes.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:5%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The amount of
	gross realized capital gains and gross realized capital losses in 2016, 2015 and 2014 were as follows:
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:5%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Gross realized loss amounts exclude OTTI losses, as discussed below.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:5%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<I>
	(e) OTTI losses
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:5%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Alleghany holds its equity and debt securities as AFS and, as such, these securities are recorded at fair value. Alleghany continually monitors
	the difference between cost and the estimated fair value of its equity and debt investments, which involves uncertainty as to whether declines in value are temporary in nature. The analysis of a security&#146;s decline in value is performed in its
	functional currency. If the decline is deemed temporary, Alleghany records the decline as an unrealized loss in stockholders&#146; equity. If the decline is deemed to be other than temporary, Alleghany writes its cost-basis or amortized cost-basis
	down to the fair value of the security and records an OTTI loss on its statement of earnings. In addition, any portion of such decline related to a debt security that is believed to arise from factors other than credit is recorded as a component of
	other comprehensive income rather than charged against earnings.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:5%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Management&#146;s assessment of equity securities initially involves an
	evaluation of all securities that are in an unrealized loss position, regardless of the duration or severity of the loss, as of the applicable balance sheet date. Such initial review consists primarily of assessing whether: (i)&nbsp;there has been a
	negative credit or news event with respect to the issuer that could indicate the existence of an OTTI; and (ii)&nbsp;Alleghany has the ability and intent to hold an equity security for a period of time sufficient to allow for an anticipated recovery
	(generally considered to be 12 months from the balance sheet date).
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:5%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	To the extent that an equity security in an unrealized loss position
	is not impaired based on the initial review described above, Alleghany then further evaluates such equity security and deems it to be other than temporarily impaired if it has been in an unrealized loss position for 12 months or more or if its
	unrealized loss position is greater than 50&nbsp;percent of its cost, absent compelling evidence to the contrary.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:5%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Alleghany then evaluates
	those equity securities where the unrealized loss is at least 20&nbsp;percent of cost as of the balance sheet date or that have been in an unrealized loss position continuously for six months or more preceding the balance sheet date. This evaluation
	takes into account quantitative and qualitative factors in determining whether such securities are other than temporarily impaired including: (i)&nbsp;market valuation metrics associated with the equity security (such as dividend yield and
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	price-to-earnings
</FONT>
</FONT>
	ratio); (ii) current views on the equity security, as expressed by either Alleghany&#146;s internal stock analysts and/or by third-party stock analysts or
	rating agencies; and (iii)&nbsp;credit or news events associated with a specific issuer, such as negative news releases and rating agency downgrades with respect to the issuer of the equity security.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:5%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Debt securities in an unrealized loss position are evaluated for OTTI if they meet any of the following criteria: (i)&nbsp;they are trading at
	a discount of at least 20&nbsp;percent to amortized cost for an extended period of time (nine consecutive months or more); (ii) there has been a negative credit or news event with respect to the issuer that could indicate the existence of an OTTI;
	or (iii) Alleghany intends to sell, or it is more likely than not that Alleghany will sell, the debt security before recovery of its amortized cost basis.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:5%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	If Alleghany intends to sell, or it is more likely than not that Alleghany will sell, a debt security before recovery of its amortized cost
	basis, the total amount of the unrealized loss position is recognized as an OTTI loss in earnings. To the extent that a debt security that is in an unrealized loss position is not impaired based on the preceding, Alleghany will consider a debt
	security to be impaired when it believes it to be probable that Alleghany will not be able to collect the entire amortized cost basis. For debt securities
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	142
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage115"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D308070D10K_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	in an unrealized loss position as of the end of each quarter, Alleghany develops a best estimate of the present value of expected cash flows. If the results of the cash flow analysis indicate
	that Alleghany will not recover the full amount of its amortized cost basis in the debt security, Alleghany records an OTTI loss in earnings equal to the difference between the present value of expected cash flows and the amortized cost basis of the
	debt security. If applicable, the difference between the total unrealized loss position on the debt security and the OTTI loss recognized in earnings is the
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	non-credit
</FONT>
	related portion, which is recorded as a
	component of other comprehensive income.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:5%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	In developing the cash flow analyses for debt securities, Alleghany considers various factors for
	the different categories of debt securities. For municipal bonds, Alleghany takes into account the taxing power of the issuer, source of revenue, credit risk and enhancements and
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	pre-refunding.
</FONT>
	For mortgage
	and asset-backed securities, Alleghany discounts its best estimate of future cash flows at an effective rate equal to the original effective yield of the security or, in the case of floating rate securities, at the current coupon. Alleghany&#146;s
	models include assumptions about prepayment speeds, default and delinquency rates, underlying collateral (if any), credit ratings, credit enhancements and other observable market data. For corporate bonds, Alleghany reviews business prospects,
	credit ratings and available information from asset managers and rating agencies for individual securities.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:5%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	OTTI losses in 2016 reflect
	$45.2&nbsp;million of unrealized losses that were deemed to be other than temporary and, as such, were required to be charged against earnings. Upon the ultimate disposition of the securities for which OTTI losses have been recorded, a portion of
	the loss may be recoverable depending on market conditions at the time of disposition. Of the $45.2&nbsp;million of OTTI losses, $23.3&nbsp;million related to equity securities, primarily in the retail, financial service, technology, chemical and
	entertainment sectors, and $21.9&nbsp;million related to debt securities, primarily in the energy sector. The determination that unrealized losses on equity and debt securities were other than temporary was primarily due to the severity and duration
	of the decline in the fair value of equity and debt securities relative to their costs.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:5%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	OTTI losses in 2015 reflect $133.9&nbsp;million of
	unrealized losses that were deemed to be other than temporary and, as such, were required to be charged against earnings. Of the $133.9&nbsp;million of OTTI losses, $115.6&nbsp;million related to equity securities, primarily in the energy,
	pharmaceutical, gaming and airline sectors, and $18.3&nbsp;million related to debt securities, primarily in the energy and financial service sectors. The determination that unrealized losses on equity and debt securities were other than temporary
	was primarily due to the fact that Alleghany lacked the intent to hold the securities for a period of time sufficient to allow for an anticipated recovery and, to a lesser extent, based on the duration of the decline in the fair value of equity
	securities relative to their costs.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:5%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	OTTI losses in 2014 reflect $36.3&nbsp;million of unrealized losses that were deemed to be other than
	temporary and, as such, were required to be charged against earnings. Of the $36.3&nbsp;million of OTTI losses, $28.7&nbsp;million relate to equity securities, primarily in the mining sector, and $7.6&nbsp;million relate to debt securities,
	primarily in the energy sector. The determination that unrealized losses on such securities were other than temporary was primarily based on the severity of the decline in the fair value of equity securities relative to their cost as of the balance
	sheet date, and the fact that Alleghany lacked the intent to hold debt securities for a period of time sufficient to allow for an anticipated recovery.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:5%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	After adjusting the cost basis of securities for the recognition of OTTI losses, the remaining gross unrealized investment losses for debt and
	equity securities as of December&nbsp;31, 2016 were deemed to be temporary, based on, among other factors: (i)&nbsp;the duration of time and the relative magnitude to which the fair value of these investments had been below cost were not indicative
	of an OTTI loss; (ii)&nbsp;the absence of compelling evidence that would cause Alleghany to call into question the financial condition or near-term business prospects of the issuer of the security; and (iii)&nbsp;Alleghany&#146;s ability and intent
	to hold the security for a period of time sufficient to allow for any anticipated recovery.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:5%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Alleghany may ultimately record a realized
	loss after having originally concluded that the decline in value was temporary. Risks and uncertainties are inherent in the methodology. Alleghany&#146;s methodology for assessing other than temporary declines in value contains inherent risks and
	uncertainties which could include, but are not limited to, incorrect assumptions about financial condition, liquidity or future prospects, inadequacy of any underlying collateral and unfavorable changes in economic conditions or social trends,
	interest rates or credit ratings.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	143
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage116"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>

<B>
<I>
	(f) Aging of Gross Unrealized Losses
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:5%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	As of December&nbsp;31, 2016 and 2015, gross unrealized losses and related fair values for equity securities and debt securities, grouped by
	duration of time in a continuous unrealized loss position, were as follows:
</P>

	&nbsp;
</P>
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<P STYLE=" MARGIN-TOP:0PT ; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; BORDER-TOP:1.00PX SOLID #000000">
	&nbsp;
</P>
</TD>
<TD>

<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<P STYLE=" MARGIN-TOP:0PT ; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; BORDER-TOP:3.00PX DOUBLE #000000">
	&nbsp;
</P>
</TD>

	&nbsp;
</P>
</TD>

</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">
	&nbsp;
</TD>

	&nbsp;
</P>

</TD>

</EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:5%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	As of December&nbsp;31, 2016, Alleghany held a total of 1,317 debt securities and equity securities that were
	in an unrealized loss position, of which 138 securities, all debt securities, were in an unrealized loss position continuously for 12 months or more. The unrealized losses associated with these debt securities consisted primarily of losses related
	to other asset-backed securities, municipal bonds and CMBS.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	144
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage117"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D308070D10K_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:5%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	As of December&nbsp;31, 2016, the vast majority of Alleghany&#146;s debt securities were rated
	investment grade, with 5.1&nbsp;percent of debt securities having issuer credit ratings that were below investment grade or not rated, compared with 3.6&nbsp;percent as of December&nbsp;31, 2015.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:5%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<I>
	(g) Statutory Deposits
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:5%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Investments with fair values of approximately $1.7&nbsp;billion as of December&nbsp;31, 2016, the substantial majority of which were debt
	securities and equity securities, were deposited with governmental authorities as required by law.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:5%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<I>
	(h) Investments in Certain Other
	Invested Assets
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:5%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	In December 2012, TransRe obtained an ownership interest in Pillar Capital Holdings Limited (&#147;Pillar
	Holdings&#148;), a Bermuda-based insurance asset manager focused on collateralized reinsurance and catastrophe insurance-linked securities. Additionally, TransRe invested $175.0&nbsp;million and AIHL invested $25.0&nbsp;million in limited
	partnership funds managed by Pillar Holdings (the &#147;Funds&#148;). The objective of the Funds is to create portfolios with attractive risk-reward characteristics and low correlation with other asset classes, using the extensive reinsurance and
	capital market experience of the principals of Pillar Holdings. Alleghany has concluded that both Pillar Holdings and the Funds (collectively, the &#147;Pillar Investments&#148;) represent variable interest entities and that Alleghany is not the
	primary beneficiary, as it does not have the ability to direct the activities that most significantly impact each entity&#146;s economic performance. Therefore, the Pillar Investments are not consolidated and are accounted for under the equity
	method of accounting. Alleghany&#146;s potential maximum loss in the Pillar Investments is limited to its cumulative net investment. As of December&nbsp;31, 2016, Alleghany&#146;s carrying value in the Pillar Investments, as determined under the
	equity method of accounting, was $233.7&nbsp;million, which is net of returns of capital received from the Pillar Investments.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:5%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	In July
	2013, AIHL invested $250.0&nbsp;million in Ares Management LLC (&#147;Ares&#148;), an asset manager, in exchange for a 6.25&nbsp;percent equity stake in Ares, with an agreement to engage Ares to manage up to $1.0&nbsp;billion in certain investment
	strategies. In May 2014, Ares completed an initial public offering of its common units. Upon completion of the initial public offering, Alleghany&#146;s equity investment in Ares converted to limited partner interests in certain Ares subsidiaries
	that are convertible into an aggregate 5.9&nbsp;percent interest in Ares common units. These interests may be converted at any time at Alleghany&#146;s discretion. Until Alleghany determines to convert its limited partner interests into Ares common
	units, Alleghany classifies its investment in Ares as a component of other invested assets and accounts for its investment using the equity method of accounting. As of December&nbsp;31, 2016, AIHL&#146;s carrying value in Ares was
	$224.0&nbsp;million, which is net of returns of capital received from Ares.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:5%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<I>
	(i) Investments in Commercial Mortgage Loans
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:5%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	As of December&nbsp;31, 2016, the carrying value of Alleghany&#146;s commercial loan portfolio was $594.9&nbsp;million,
	representing the unpaid principal balance on the loans. As of December&nbsp;31, 2016, there was no allowance for loan losses. The commercial loan portfolio consists primarily of first mortgages on commercial properties in major metropolitan areas in
	the U.S. The loans earn interest at fixed- and floating-rates, mature in two to ten years and the principal amounts of the loans were no more than approximately
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	two-thirds
</FONT>
	of the property&#146;s appraised
	value at the time the loan was made.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
</B>
<B>
<I>
	5.
</I>
</B>
<B>
	Reinsurance Ceded
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:5%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<I>
	(a) Overview
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:5%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Alleghany&#146;s reinsurance and insurance subsidiaries reinsure portions of the risks they underwrite in order to reduce the effect of
	individual or aggregate exposure to losses, manage capacity, protect capital resources, reduce volatility in specific lines of business, improve risk-adjusted portfolio returns and enable them to increase gross premium writings and risk capacity
	without requiring additional capital. Alleghany&#146;s reinsurance and insurance subsidiaries purchase reinsurance and retrocessional coverages from highly-rated third-party reinsurers. If the assuming reinsurers are unable or unwilling to meet the
	obligations assumed under the applicable reinsurance agreements, Alleghany&#146;s reinsurance and insurance subsidiaries would remain liable for such reinsurance portion not paid by these reinsurers. As such, funds, trust agreements and letters of
	credit are held to collateralize a portion of Alleghany&#146;s reinsurance recoverables and Alleghany&#146;s reinsurance and insurance subsidiaries reinsure portions of the risks they underwrite or assume with multiple reinsurance programs.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	145
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage118"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D308070D10K_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:5%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<I>
	(b) Reinsurance Recoverables
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:5%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Amounts recoverable from reinsurers are recognized in a manner consistent with the claims liabilities associated with the reinsurance placement
	and presented on the balance sheet as reinsurance recoverables. Such balances as of December&nbsp;31, 2016 and 2015 consisted of the following:
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:12PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">

	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:8PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="3%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	(1)
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	Reinsurance recoverables reflect amounts due from one or more reinsurance subsidiaries of the listed company.
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:8PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="3%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	(2)
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	Represents the A.M. Best financial strength rating for the applicable reinsurance subsidiary or subsidiaries from which the reinsurance recoverable is due.
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:8PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="3%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	(3)
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	In December 2016, Fairfax Financial Holdings Ltd announced its agreement to acquire Allied World Assurance Company Holdings, AG.
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:8PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="3%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	(4)
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	Approximately 94&nbsp;percent of our reinsurance recoverables balance as of December&nbsp;31, 2016 was due from reinsurers having an A.M. Best financial strength rating of A (Excellent) or higher.
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:8PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="3%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	(5)
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	Represents reinsurance recoverables secured by funds held, trust agreements and letters of credit.
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:5%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Alleghany had no allowance for uncollectible reinsurance as of December&nbsp;31, 2016 and 2015.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:5%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Reinsured loss and LAE ceded included in Alleghany&#146;s consolidated statements of earnings were $325.8&nbsp;million, $309.6&nbsp;million and
	$250.3&nbsp;million for 2016, 2015 and 2014, respectively.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:5%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<I>
	(d) Significant Reinsurance Contracts
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:5%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Alleghany&#146;s reinsurance and insurance subsidiaries reinsure portions of the risks they underwrite or assume with multiple reinsurance
	programs. A discussion of the more significant programs follows.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:5%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	RSUI reinsures its property lines of business through a program
	consisting of surplus share treaties, facultative placements, per risk and catastrophe excess of loss treaties. RSUI&#146;s catastrophe reinsurance program and property per risk reinsurance program run on an annual basis from May&nbsp;1 to the
	following April 30.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:5%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	RSUI&#146;s catastrophe reinsurance program covers catastrophe risks including, among others, windstorms and
	earthquakes. As of December&nbsp;31, 2016, the catastrophe reinsurance program consisted of three layers, with portions of the first and second layers placed on May&nbsp;1, 2015 and May&nbsp;1, 2016 and portions of the third layer placed on
	May&nbsp;1, 2014 and May&nbsp;1, 2016. The catastrophe reinsurance program provides coverage for $600.0&nbsp;million of losses in excess of a $200.0&nbsp;million net retention after application of surplus share treaties and facultative reinsurance.
	The first layer provides coverage for $300.0&nbsp;million of losses, subject to a 5.0&nbsp;percent
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	co-participation
</FONT>
	by RSUI in excess of $200.0&nbsp;million, the second layer provides coverage for
	$100.0&nbsp;million of losses in excess of $500.0&nbsp;million, with no
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	co-participation
</FONT>
	by RSUI and the third layer provides coverage for $200.0&nbsp;million of losses in excess of $600.0&nbsp;million, with
	no
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	co-participation
</FONT>
	by RSUI. The first and second layers of coverage include the following expiration terms: approximately 34&nbsp;percent of coverage limits, which originally expired on April&nbsp;30, 2016
	and was renewed May&nbsp;1, 2016, currently expires on April&nbsp;30, 2019; approximately 33&nbsp;percent of coverage limits expire on April&nbsp;30, 2017; and approximately 33&nbsp;percent of coverage limits expire on April&nbsp;30, 2018. The third
	layer of coverage originally expired on April&nbsp;30, 2017. However, effective May&nbsp;1, 2016, approximately 39&nbsp;percent of the third layer of coverage was cancelled and replaced with the same coverage for a three year period expiring on
	April&nbsp;30, 2019. The remaining coverage limits expire on April&nbsp;30, 2017.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:5%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	In addition, RSUI&#146;s property per risk reinsurance
	program runs on an annual basis from May&nbsp;1 to the following April&nbsp;30 and thus expired on April&nbsp;30, 2016. On May&nbsp;1, 2016, the property per risk program was renewed and the new program will expire on April&nbsp;30, 2017. For the
	2016 to 2017 period, RSUI&#146;s property per risk reinsurance program provides coverage for $90.0&nbsp;million of losses, subject to a 10.0&nbsp;percent
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	co-participation
</FONT>
	by RSUI, in excess of a
	$10.0&nbsp;million net retention per risk after application of surplus share treaties and facultative reinsurance.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:5%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<I>
	(e) Significant
	Intercompany Reinsurance Contracts
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:5%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	In the second quarter of 2013, AIHL Re and PacificComp&#146;s wholly-owned subsidiary Pacific
	Compensation Insurance Company (&#147;PCIC&#148;), entered into an intercompany reinsurance contract, effective January&nbsp;1, 2013, pursuant to which AIHL Re provides PCIC with coverage for adverse development on net loss and allocated LAE in
	excess of PCIC&#146;s carried reserves at December&nbsp;31, 2012 and accident year stop-loss coverage for any net losses and allocated LAE in excess of 75.0&nbsp;percent of net premiums earned for PCIC for accident years 2013 through 2017. AIHL
	Re&#146;s commitments also are intended to cover the statutory collateral requirements at PCIC, if and when necessary. AIHL Re&#146;s obligations are subject to an aggregate limit of $100.0&nbsp;million. In connection with such intercompany
	reinsurance agreement, Alleghany and AIHL Re entered into a contract whereby Alleghany will guarantee the recoverable balances owed to PCIC from AIHL Re up to $100.0&nbsp;million. Subsequent to the entry into the above agreements, A.M. Best Company,
	Inc. upgraded PCIC&#146;s rating to
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	A-
</FONT>
	(Excellent) from B++ (Good). The above agreements had no impact on Alleghany&#146;s consolidated results of operations and financial condition.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:5%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	In the third quarter of 2015, AIHL Re and CapSpecialty (specifically, the insurance subsidiaries of CapSpecialty) entered into an intercompany
	reinsurance contract, effective July&nbsp;1, 2015, pursuant to which AIHL Re provides CapSpecialty with coverage
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	147
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage120"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D308070D10K_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	primarily for adverse development on certain net loss and allocated LAE in excess of its carried reserves at June&nbsp;30, 2015. AIHL Re&#146;s commitments are intended to cover the statutory
	collateral requirements at CapSpecialty, if and when necessary, and AIHL Re&#146;s obligations are subject to an aggregate limit of $50.0&nbsp;million. In connection with such intercompany reinsurance agreement, Alleghany and AIHL Re entered into a
	contract whereby Alleghany will guarantee the recoverable balances owed to CapSpecialty from AIHL Re up to $50.0&nbsp;million. The above agreements had no impact on Alleghany&#146;s consolidated results of operations and financial condition.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	6. Liability for Loss and LAE
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:5%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<I>
	(a)
	Liability Rollforward
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:5%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Activity in liability for loss and LAE in 2016, 2015 and 2014 is summarized as follows:

<P STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT:13.0PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:2PT;BORDER-BOTTOM:1PX SOLID #000000;WIDTH:16%">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:8PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="3%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	(1)
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	Reinsurance recoverables in this table include only ceded loss and LAE reserves.
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:8PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="3%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	(2)
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	Represents reserves acquired in connection with a loss portfolio transfer transaction.
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:8PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="3%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	(3)
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	Includes paid losses, net of reinsurance, related to commutations.
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:6%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Gross loss and LAE
	reserves as of December&nbsp;31, 2016 increased from December&nbsp;31, 2015, reflecting increases in the reinsurance and insurance segments. The increase in gross loss and LAE reserves at the reinsurance segment primarily reflects the impact of
	higher net premiums earned and higher catastrophe losses, partially offset by favorable prior accident year loss reserve development. The increase in gross loss and LAE reserves at the insurance segment primarily reflects higher current accident
	year losses and higher catastrophe losses, partially offset by favorable prior accident year loss reserve development.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:5%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Gross loss and LAE
	reserves as of December&nbsp;31, 2015 decreased from December&nbsp;31, 2014, reflecting a decrease in the reinsurance segment loss and LAE reserves, partially offset by an increase in the insurance segment. The decrease in gross loss and LAE
	reserves in the reinsurance segment primarily reflects favorable prior accident year loss reserve development, loss payments including amounts related to commutations in the fourth quarter of 2015 with certain cedants and the impact of changes in
	foreign currency exchange rates. The increase in gross loss and LAE reserves in the insurance segment primarily reflects higher current accident year losses.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	148
</P>

	(b) Liability Development

</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:5%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The (favorable) unfavorable prior accident year loss reserve development for 2016, 2015 and 2014 is summarized as follows:
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE CELLSPACING="0" CELLPADDING="0" WIDTH="86%" BORDER="0" STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT">

<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:8PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="3%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	(1)
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	Reflects favorable prior accident year loss reserve development from several catastrophes that occurred in the 2010 through 2015 accident years.
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:8PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="3%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	(2)
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	Includes favorable prior accident year loss reserve development of ($27.7) million from Super Storm Sandy in 2012 and various smaller amounts on catastrophes that occurred in the 2010, 2011, 2013 and 2014 accident
	years, partially offset by unfavorable prior accident year development from the New Zealand earthquake in 2010.
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:8PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="3%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	(3)
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	Includes favorable prior accident year loss reserve development of ($1.6) million from Super Storm Sandy in 2012 and ($15.7) million of net favorable prior accident year loss reserve development from other catastrophes.
	The ($15.7) million primarily reflects favorable prior accident year loss reserve development from several catastrophes that occurred primarily in the 2011 and 2013 accident years, partially offset by unfavorable prior accident year loss reserve
	development from the New Zealand earthquake in 2010.
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:8PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="3%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	(4)
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	Reflects favorable prior accident year loss reserve development primarily related to the 2011 and 2015 accident years.
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:8PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="3%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	(5)
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	Reflects favorable prior accident year loss reserve development primarily related to the 2013 and 2014 accident years.
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:8PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="3%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	(6)
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	Reflects favorable prior accident year loss reserve development primarily related to the 2012 accident year and, to a lesser extent, the 2011 accident year.
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:8PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="3%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	(7)
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	Represents certain medical malpractice treaties pursuant to which the increased underwriting profits created by the favorable prior accident year loss reserve development are largely retained by the cedants. As a
	result, the favorable prior accident year development is largely offset by an increase in profit commission expense incurred when such favorable prior accident year loss reserve development occurs.
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:8PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="3%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	(8)
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	Represents unfavorable prior accident year loss reserve development related to a commutation and release agreement entered into on November&nbsp;30, 2015 by TransRe with AIG Property Casualty, Inc., National Indemnity
	Company and Resolute Management, Inc. with respect to certain reinsurance contracts (the &#147;Commutation Agreement&#148;), including contracts covering asbestos-related illness and environmental impairment liabilities for 1986 and prior years (the
	&#147;Commuted A&amp;E Liabilities&#148;).
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:8PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="3%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	(9)
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	Generally reflects favorable prior accident year loss reserve development in a variety of casualty&nbsp;&amp; other lines of business primarily from the 2003 through 2015 accident years.
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:8PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="3%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	(10)
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	Generally reflects favorable prior accident year loss reserve development in a variety of casualty&nbsp;&amp; other lines of business primarily from the 2005 through 2014 accident years, including ($30.7) million of
	favorable prior accident year development related to French medical malpractice loss reserves commuted in the fourth quarter of 2015 with a European cedant, partially offset by unfavorable prior accident year development from the 2004 and prior
	accident years.
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>

<TR>
<TD WIDTH="3%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	(11)
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	Generally reflects favorable prior accident year loss reserve development in a variety of casualty &amp; other lines of business primarily from the 2003 through 2007 and 2010 through 2011 accident years, partially
	offset by unfavorable prior accident year loss reserve development from the 2013 accident year and the 2002 and prior accident years.
</TD>

<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:8PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="3%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	(12)
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	Primarily reflects favorable prior accident year loss reserve development in the umbrella/excess, general liability and professional liability lines of business related to the 2006 through 2012 accident years.
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:8PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="3%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	(13)
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	Primarily reflects favorable prior accident year loss reserve development in the umbrella/excess, general liability and professional liability lines of business related to the 2006 through 2011 accident years, partially
	offset by unfavorable prior accident year loss reserve development in the directors&#146; and officers&#146; liability lines of business related to the 2011 through 2014 accident years.
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:8PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="3%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	(14)
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	Primarily reflects favorable prior accident year loss reserve development in the professional liability, general liability and umbrella/excess lines of business, and primarily related to the 2006 through 2010 accident
	years, partially offset by unfavorable prior accident year loss reserve development in the directors&#146; and officers&#146; liability lines of business in the 2011 and 2012 accident years.
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:8PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="3%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	(15)
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	Includes favorable prior accident year loss reserve development of ($20.6) million from Super Storm Sandy in 2012 and various other smaller amounts primarily from the non-catastrophe property lines of business in recent
	accident years.
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:8PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="3%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	(16)
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	Primarily reflects favorable prior accident year development of ($4.1) million from Super Storm Sandy in 2012, net of reinsurance, and favorable prior accident year loss reserve development related to unallocated LAE
	reserves.
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:8PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="3%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	(17)
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	Primarily reflects favorable prior accident year development on unallocated LAE reserves and prior year catastrophe loss reserves from recent accident years.
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:8PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="3%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	(18)
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	Primarily reflects unfavorable prior accident year loss reserve development related to the casualty lines of business from the 2011 through 2013 accident years.
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:8PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="3%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	(19)
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	Represents certain specialty lines of business written through a program administrator in connection with a terminated program related to the 2010 and 2009 accident years and reflects (favorable) loss emergence compared
	with loss emergence patterns assumed in earlier periods for such business.
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:8PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="3%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	(20)
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	Primarily reflects favorable prior accident year loss reserve development related to 2012 and prior accident years.
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:8PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="3%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	(21)
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	Primarily reflects unfavorable prior accident year loss reserve development related to 2009 and prior accident years.
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:5%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<I>
	(c) Supplementary Information on Incurred and Paid Loss and LAE Development
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:5%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The following is supplemental information about incurred and paid loss and LAE development, net of reinsurance. Information is also included
	for the portion of unpaid loss and LAE, net of reinsurance recoverables, that relate to IBNR and, for the insurance segment, the cumulative number of reported insurance claims.
</P>

<TR BGCOLOR="#CCEEFF" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:7PT">
<TD VALIGN="TOP" COLSPAN="36">
<P STYLE=" MARGIN-TOP:0PT ; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:0.86EM; TEXT-INDENT:-0.86EM; FONT-SIZE:7PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;Cumulative Paid Loss and LAE for the 2007 through 2016 accident
	years
</P>

<P STYLE=" MARGIN-TOP:0PT ; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; BORDER-TOP:3.00PX DOUBLE #000000">
	&nbsp;
</P>
</TD>
<TD>
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
</EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<P STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT:13.0PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:2PT;BORDER-BOTTOM:1PX SOLID #000000;WIDTH:16%">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:8PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="3%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	(1)
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	The vast majority of the CapSpecialty&#146;s loss and LAE reserves relate to its casualty lines of business.
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:8PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="3%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	(2)
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	Represents claims reported by insured claimants.
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>

	&nbsp;

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	7. Credit Agreements
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:5%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	On October&nbsp;15, 2013, Alleghany entered into a four-year credit agreement (the &#147;Credit Agreement&#148;) which provides for an
	unsecured credit facility in an aggregate principal amount of up to $200.0&nbsp;million. The Credit Agreement is scheduled to terminate on October&nbsp;15, 2017, unless terminated at an earlier date. Borrowings under the Credit Agreement will be
	available for working capital and general corporate purposes.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:5%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Borrowings under the Credit Agreement bear a floating rate of interest based
	in part on Alleghany&#146;s credit rating, among other factors. The Credit Agreement requires that all loans be repaid in full no later than October&nbsp;15, 2017. The Credit Agreement also requires Alleghany to pay a commitment fee each quarter in
	a range of between 0.125 and 0.30&nbsp;percent per annum, based upon
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	156
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage129"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D308070D10K_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Alleghany&#146;s credit rating, on the daily unused amount of the commitments. The Credit Agreement contains representations, warranties and covenants customary for bank loan facilities of this
	nature.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:5%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	In the fourth quarter of 2015, Alleghany borrowed and repaid $60.0&nbsp;million under the Credit Agreement. As of
	December&nbsp;31, 2016, there were no outstanding borrowings under the Credit Agreement.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:5%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	In addition to the Credit Agreement, several of
	Alleghany Capital&#146;s subsidiaries have credit agreements with third-party financial institutions. Any borrowings under such agreements are not guaranteed by Alleghany or Alleghany Capital. See Note 8(c) for information on the borrowings arising
	from these credit agreements.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	8. Debt
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:5%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<I>
	(a) Alleghany Senior Notes
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:5%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	On September&nbsp;9, 2014, Alleghany completed a public offering of $300.0&nbsp;million aggregate principal amount of its 4.90% senior notes
	due on September&nbsp;15, 2044 (the &#147;2044 Senior Notes&#148;). The 2044 Senior Notes are unsecured and unsubordinated general obligations of Alleghany. Interest on the 2044 Senior Notes is payable semi-annually on March&nbsp;15 and
	September&nbsp;15 of each year. The terms of the 2044 Senior Notes permit redemption prior to their maturity. The indenture under which the 2044 Senior Notes were issued contains covenants that impose conditions on Alleghany&#146;s ability to create
	liens on, or engage in sales of, the capital stock of AIHL, TransRe or RSUI. The 2044 Senior Notes were issued at approximately 99.3&nbsp;percent of par, resulting in proceeds after underwriting discount, commissions and other expenses of
	$294.3&nbsp;million and an effective yield of approximately 5.0&nbsp;percent.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:5%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	On June&nbsp;26, 2012, Alleghany completed a public offering
	of $400.0&nbsp;million aggregate principal amount of its 4.95% senior notes due on June&nbsp;27, 2022 (the &#147;2022 Senior Notes&#148;). The 2022 Senior Notes are unsecured and unsubordinated general obligations of Alleghany. Interest on the 2022
	Senior Notes is payable semi-annually on June&nbsp;27 and December&nbsp;27 of each year. The terms of the 2022 Senior Notes permit redemption prior to their maturity. The indenture under which the 2022 Senior Notes were issued contains covenants
	that impose conditions on Alleghany&#146;s ability to create liens on, or engage in sales of, the capital stock of AIHL, TransRe or RSUI. The 2022 Senior Notes were issued at approximately 99.9&nbsp;percent of par, resulting in proceeds after
	underwriting discount, commissions and other expenses of $396.0&nbsp;million and an effective yield of approximately 5.05&nbsp;percent.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:5%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	On
	September&nbsp;20, 2010, Alleghany completed a public offering of $300.0&nbsp;million aggregate principal amount of its
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	5.625% senior notes due on
	September&nbsp;15, 2020 (the &#147;2020 Senior Notes&#148;). The 2020 Senior Notes are unsecured and unsubordinated general obligations of Alleghany. Interest on the 2020 Senior Notes is payable semi-annually on March&nbsp;15 and September&nbsp;15
	of each year. The terms of the 2020 Senior Notes permit redemption prior to their maturity. The indenture under which the 2020 Senior Notes were issued contains covenants that impose conditions on Alleghany&#146;s ability to create liens on, or
	engage in sales of, the capital stock of AIHL or RSUI. The 2020 Senior Notes were issued at approximately 99.6&nbsp;percent of par, resulting in proceeds after underwriting discount, commissions and other expenses of $298.9&nbsp;million and an
	effective yield of approximately 5.67&nbsp;percent.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:5%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<I>
	(b) TransRe Senior Notes
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:5%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	On December&nbsp;14, 2005, TransRe completed a public offering of $750.0&nbsp;million aggregate principal amount of its 2015 Senior Notes.
	Prior to the merger with TransRe, a portion of the 2015 Senior Notes was repurchased by TransRe. On October&nbsp;15, 2014, TransRe redeemed $300.0&nbsp;million aggregate principal amount of the 2015 Senior Notes for $324.4&nbsp;million, consisting
	of the $300.0&nbsp;million aggregate principal amount redeemed, $18.6&nbsp;million of redemption premium and $5.8&nbsp;million of accrued and unpaid interest to the date of redemption. Of the $324.4&nbsp;million redemption amount,
	$297.3&nbsp;million was funded by a capital contribution from Alleghany primarily using the $294.3&nbsp;million of net proceeds from Alleghany&#146;s issuance of the 2044 Senior Notes. As a result of this early extinguishment of debt, TransRe
	recorded a realized loss, before tax, of $9.4&nbsp;million in 2014. On December&nbsp;14, 2015, the remaining $367.0&nbsp;million outstanding aggregate principal amount of TransRe&#146;s 2015 Senior Notes matured and was repaid.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:5%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	On November&nbsp;23, 2009, TransRe completed a public offering of $350.0&nbsp;million aggregate principal amount of its 8.00% senior notes due
	on November&nbsp;30, 2039 (the &#147;2039 Senior Notes&#148;). The 2039 Senior Notes are unsecured and unsubordinated general obligations of TransRe and are not guaranteed by Alleghany. Interest on the 2039 Senior Notes is payable semi-annually. The
	terms of the 2039 Senior Notes permit redemption prior to their maturity. The indentures under which the 2039 Senior Notes were issued contain covenants that impose conditions on TransRe&#146;s ability to create liens on, or engage in sales of, the
	capital stock of certain of its subsidiaries, including Transatlantic Reinsurance Company, TransRe Zurich Ltd. or Fair American Insurance and Reinsurance Company.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:5%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<I>
	(c) Alleghany Capital Operating Subsidiaries
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:5%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The debt associated with Alleghany Capital&#146;s operating subsidiaries totaled $92.8&nbsp;million and $36.3&nbsp;million as of
	December&nbsp;31, 2016 and 2015, respectively. As of December&nbsp;31, 2016, the $92.8&nbsp;million includes $41.0&nbsp;million of debt at Kentucky Trailer related primarily to a mortgage loan, borrowings to finance small acquisitions and borrowings
	under its available credit facility, $31.2&nbsp;million of borrowings by Jazwares under its available credit facility and $20.6&nbsp;million of debt at Bourn&nbsp;&amp; Koch related to borrowings to finance an acquisition. None of these liabilities
	are guaranteed by Alleghany or Alleghany Capital.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	157
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage130"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D308070D10K_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	9. Income Taxes

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:5%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Income before income taxes from domestic operations was $407.7&nbsp;million, $376.7&nbsp;million and
	$633.8&nbsp;million in 2016, 2015 and 2014, respectfully. Income before income taxes from foreign operations was $240.1&nbsp;million, $380.7&nbsp;million and $298.1&nbsp;million in 2016, 2015 and 2014, respectively. Foreign tax expense was primarily
	attributable to the United Kingdom (the &#147;U.K.&#148;).
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:5%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The difference between the federal income tax rate and the effective income tax
	rate was as follows:
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:5%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The increase in the effective tax rate in 2016 from 2015 primarily reflects larger prior period income tax
	expense adjustments, higher state income taxes and lower
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	tax-exempt
</FONT>
	interest income arising from municipal bond securities. Prior period income tax expense adjustments for 2016 include $16.1&nbsp;million of
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	out-of-period
</FONT>
</FONT>
	reductions to current and deferred TransRe tax assets recorded in 2016 that relate primarily to periods prior to the merger with TransRe in 2012.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:5%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The slight decrease in the effective tax rate in 2015 compared with 2014 primarily reflects lower taxable income in 2015, partially offset by
	lower interest income arising from municipal bond securities.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	158
</P>

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:5%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	A valuation allowance is provided against deferred tax assets when, in the opinion of management, it is more
	likely than not that a portion of the deferred tax asset will not be realized. As of December&nbsp;31, 2016 and 2015, Alleghany recognized $25.2&nbsp;million and $17.9&nbsp;million, respectively, of deferred tax assets for certain state net
	operating and capital loss carryovers, and a valuation allowance of $25.2&nbsp;million and $17.9&nbsp;million, respectively, has been established against these deferred tax assets as Alleghany does not currently anticipate it will generate
	sufficient income in these states to absorb such loss carryovers.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:5%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The Internal Revenue Code provides for limits on the utilization of
	certain tax benefits following a corporate ownership change. Upon the closing of the merger with TransRe, TransRe was subject to an annual limitation on its ability to use its foreign tax credit carryforwards and its minimum tax credit
	carryforwards. The total amount of foreign tax credit carryforwards and minimum tax credit carryforwards that were available prior to the merger are not diminished by this provision. The limitation provides for an annual limit on the amount of the
	carryforwards that can be used each year. The unused carryovers are available to be used in subsequent years, subject to the annual limitation. The annual limitation is estimated at approximately $42.7&nbsp;million.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:5%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Alleghany&#146;s income tax returns are currently under examination by the Internal Revenue Service for the 2012, 2013 and 2014 tax years.
	TransRe&#146;s income tax returns, which all relate to periods prior to the merger with Alleghany, are currently under examination by the Internal Revenue Service. The following table lists the tax years of Alleghany and TransRe tax returns that
	remain subject to examination by major tax jurisdictions as of December&nbsp;31, 2016.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>

<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D308070D10K_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:5%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Alleghany believes that, as of December&nbsp;31, 2016, it had no material uncertain tax
	positions. Interest and penalties relating to unrecognized tax expenses (benefits) are recognized in income tax expense, when applicable. There were no material liabilities for interest or penalties accrued as of December&nbsp;31, 2016.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	10. Stockholders&#146; Equity
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:5%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<I>
	(a)
	Common Stock Repurchases
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:5%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	In October 2012, the Alleghany Board of Directors authorized the repurchase of shares of Common Stock, at
	such times and at prices as management determined to be advisable, up to an aggregate of $300.0&nbsp;million (the &#147;2012 Repurchase Program&#148;). In July 2014, the Alleghany Board of Directors authorized, upon the completion of the 2012
	Repurchase Program, the repurchase of shares of Common Stock at such times and at prices as management determines to be advisable, up to an aggregate of $350.0&nbsp;million (the &#147;2014 Repurchase Program&#148;). In the fourth quarter of 2014,
	Alleghany completed the 2012 Repurchase Program and subsequent repurchases have been made pursuant to the 2014 Repurchase Program. In November 2015, the Alleghany Board of Directors authorized the repurchase, upon the completion of the 2014
	Repurchase Program, of additional shares of Common Stock, at such times and at prices as management determines to be advisable, up to an aggregate of $400.0&nbsp;million (the &#147;2015 Repurchase Program&#148;). In the first quarter of 2016,
	Alleghany completed the 2014 Repurchase Program and subsequent repurchases have been made pursuant to the 2015 Repurchase Program. As of December&nbsp;31, 2016, Alleghany had $379.2&nbsp;million remaining under its share repurchase authorization.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:5%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Pursuant to the 2012 Repurchase Program, 2014 Repurchase Program and the 2015 Repurchase Program, as applicable, Alleghany repurchased
	shares of Common Stock in 2016, 2015 and 2014 as follows:
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>

</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:8PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="3%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	(1)
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	For 2016, excludes a ($98.8) million impairment charge from a write-down of certain SORC assets and the Jazwares Remeasurement Gain of $13.2&nbsp;million. For 2015, excludes a ($25.8) million realized capital loss
	related to an impairment charge related to a
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	write-off
</FONT>
	of Alleghany&#146;s investment in ORX.
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:5%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<I>
	(c) Regulations and Dividend Restrictions
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:5%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	As of December&nbsp;31, 2016, approximately $6.6&nbsp;billion of Alleghany&#146;s total equity of $7.9&nbsp;billion was unavailable for
	dividends or advances to Alleghany from its subsidiaries. The remaining $1.3&nbsp;billion was available for dividends or advances to Alleghany from its subsidiaries, or was retained at the Alleghany parent company-level and, as such, was available
	to pay dividends to Alleghany&#146;s stockholders as of December&nbsp;31, 2016.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:5%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The ability of Alleghany&#146;s reinsurance and insurance
	subsidiaries to pay dividends or other distributions is subject to the laws and regulations applicable to each subsidiary, as well as each subsidiary&#146;s need to maintain capital requirements adequate to maintain its operations and financial
	strength ratings issued by independent rating agencies.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:5%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	In the U.S., Alleghany&#146;s reinsurance and insurance subsidiaries are subject
	to insurance laws and regulations that restrict the amount and timing of dividends they may pay without the prior approval of regulatory authorities. Under the insurance holding company laws and regulations, Alleghany&#146;s reinsurance and
	insurance subsidiaries may not pay an &#147;extraordinary&#148; dividend or distribution without the approval of state insurance regulators. In general, an &#147;extraordinary&#148; dividend or distribution is defined as a dividend or distribution
	that, together with other dividends and distributions made within the preceding 12 months, exceeds the lesser (or, in some jurisdictions, the greater) of (i) 10&nbsp;percent of the statutory surplus of the reinsurer or insurer as of the end of the
	prior calendar year (or, in certain states, as of the end of the prior quarter) and (ii)&nbsp;the net income during the prior calendar year (or, in certain states, the adjusted statutory net investment income). In addition, certain states where
	Alleghany&#146;s reinsurance and insurance subsidiaries are domiciled prohibit a domestic insurance company from paying dividends except out of earned surplus.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:5%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	TransRe&#146;s operations are also regulated in various foreign jurisdictions with respect to currency, amount and type of security deposits,
	amount and type of reserves and amount and type of local investment. Regulations governing constitution of technical reserves and remittance balances in some countries may hinder remittance of profits and repatriation of assets. International
	operations and assets held abroad may also be adversely affected by political and other developments in foreign countries, including possible tax changes, nationalization and changes in regulatory policy, as well as by consequences of hostilities
	and unrest. The risks of such occurrences and their overall effect upon TransRe vary from country to country and cannot easily be predicted.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:5%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	A summary of dividends paid to Alleghany by its reinsurance and insurance subsidiaries in 2016, 2015 and 2014 follows:
</P>

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:5%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	As of December&nbsp;31, 2016, a maximum amount of $15.0&nbsp;million was available for dividends by TRC without prior approval of the
	applicable regulatory authorities.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:5%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The statutory net income of Alleghany&#146;s reinsurance and insurance subsidiaries was
	$688.9&nbsp;million and $741.0&nbsp;million for the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2016 and 2015, respectively. As of December&nbsp;31, 2016 and 2015, the combined statutory capital and surplus of Alleghany&#146;s reinsurance and insurance
	subsidiaries was $6.7&nbsp;billion and $6.6&nbsp;billion, respectively. As of December&nbsp;31, 2016, the amount of statutory capital and surplus necessary to satisfy regulatory requirements was not significant in relation to the actual statutory
	capital and surplus of Alleghany&#146;s reinsurance and insurance companies in the U.S.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	161
</P>
